Create a 2-1 multiplexer. When sel=0, choose a. When sel=1, choose b.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

prompt:
module top_module(
	input [3:1] y,
	input w,
	output reg Y2);
completion:
module top_module(
    input [3:1] y,
    input w,
    output reg Y2);

    always @(*) begin
        case (y)
            3'b000: Y2 = 0; // A
            3'b001: Y2 = 0; // B
            3'b010: Y2 = ~w; // C
            3'b011: Y2 = ~w; // D
            3'b100: Y2 = ~w; // E
            3'b101: Y2 = 0; // F
            default: Y2 = 0;
        endcase
    end

endmodule

	input clk,
	input load,
	input ena,
	input [1:0] amount,
	input [63:0] data,
	output reg [63:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input ena,
    input [1:0] amount,
    input [63:0] data,
    output reg [63:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else if (ena) begin
            case (amount)
                2'b00: q <= {q[62:0], 1'b0};          // Shift Left by 1
                2'b01: q <= {q[55:0], 8'b0};          // Shift Left by 8
                2'b10: q <= {q[63], q[63:1]};        // Arithmetic Shift Right by 1
                2'b11: q <= { {8{q[63]}}, q[63:8]};  // Arithmetic Shift Right by 8
                default: q <= q;
            endcase
        end
    end

endmodule

Consider an n-bit shift register circuit. Inputs E are for enabling shift, R for value to load, L is asserted when it should load, and w is the input to the first stage of the shift register. Write a Verilog module named top_module for one stage of this circuit, including both the flip-flop and multiplexers.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module (
	input clk,
	input w,
	input R,
	input E,
	input L,
	output reg Q
);

module top_module (
	input a, 
	input b, 
	input c, 
	input d,
	output q
);

module top_module(
	input clk,
	input load,
	input [511:0] data,
	output reg [511:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input [511:0] data,
    output reg [511:0] q);

    reg [511:0] next_q;

    always @(*) begin
        for (int i = 0; i < 512; i++) begin
            // Rule 110 implementation
            next_q[i] = (
                ((i > 0) ? q[i-1] : 0) && q[i] && ((i < 511) ? ~q[i+1] : 1) ||
                ((i > 0) ? q[i-1] : 0) && ~q[i] && ((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 0) ||
                ((i > 0) ? ~q[i-1] : 1) && q[i] && ((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 0) ||
                ((i > 0) ? ~q[i-1] : 1) && q[i] && ((i < 511) ? ~q[i+1] : 1) ||
                ((i > 0) ? ~q[i-1] : 1) && ~q[i] && ((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 0)
            );
        end
    end

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else begin
            q <= next_q;
        end
    end

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

For each bit in a 32-bit vector, capture when the input signal changes from 1 in one clock cycle to 0 the next. "Capture" means that the output will remain 1 until the register is reset (active high synchronous reset).
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input [31:0] in,
	output reg [31:0] out);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input reset,
    input [31:0] in,
    output reg [31:0] out);

    reg [31:0] in_prev;

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (reset) begin
            out <= 0;
        end else begin
            for (int i = 0; i < 32; i++) begin
                if (in_prev[i] == 1 && in[i] == 0) begin
                    out[i] <= 1;
                end
            end
        end
        in_prev <= in;
    end

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Build a two-bit saturating counter. The counter increments (up to a maximum of 3) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 1. It decrements (down to a minimum of 0) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 0. When not training (train_valid = 0), the counter keeps its value unchanged. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the counter to weakly not-taken (2'b01). Output state[1:0] is the two-bit counter value.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);

    always_ff @(posedge clk, posedge areset) begin
        if (areset) begin
            state <= 2'b01;
        end else begin
            if (train_valid) begin
                if (train_taken) begin
                    if (state < 2'b11) begin
                        state <= state + 1;
                    end
                end else begin
                    if (state > 2'b00) begin
                        state <= state - 1;
                    end
                end
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

Build a priority encoder for 8-bit inputs. Given an 8-bit vector, the output should report the first (least significant) bit in the vector that is 1. Report zero if the input vector has no bits that are high. For example, the input 8'b10010000 should output 3'd4, because bit[4] is first bit that is high.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

prompt:
module top_module (
	input [15:0] scancode,
	output reg left,
	output reg down,
	output reg right,
	output reg up
);
completion:
module top_module (
    input [15:0] scancode,
    output reg left,
    output reg down,
    output reg right,
    output reg up
);

    always @(*) begin
        case (scancode)
            16'he06b: begin left = 1; down = 0; right = 0; up = 0; end
            16'he072: begin left = 0; down = 1; right = 0; up = 0; end
            16'he074: begin left = 0; down = 0; right = 1; up = 0; end
            16'he075: begin left = 0; down = 0; right = 0; up = 1; end
            default:  begin left = 0; down = 0; right = 0; up = 0; end
        endcase
    end

endmodule

You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Build a 32-bit global history shift register, including support for rolling back state in response to a pipeline flush caused by a branch misprediction. When a branch prediction is made (predict_valid = 1), shift in predict_taken from the LSB side to update the branch history for the predicted branch. (predict_history[0] is the direction of the youngest branch.) When a branch misprediction occurs (train_mispredicted = 1), load the branch history register with the history after the completion of the mispredicted branch. This is the history before the mispredicted branch (train_history) concatenated with the actual result of the branch (train_taken). If both a prediction and misprediction occur at the same time, the misprediction takes precedence, because the pipeline flush will also flush out the branch that is currently making a prediction. predict_history is the value of the branch history register. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the history counter to zero.


Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module
(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input predict_valid,
    input predict_taken,
    output logic [31:0] predict_history,
    
    input train_mispredicted,
    input train_taken,
    input [31:0] train_history
);
completion:
module top_module
(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input predict_valid,
    input predict_taken,
    output logic [31:0] predict_history,
    
    input train_mispredicted,
    input train_taken,
    input [31:0] train_history
);

    reg [31:0] history;

    always @(posedge clk or posedge areset) begin
        if (areset) begin
            history <= 32'b0;
        end else begin
            if (train_mispredicted) begin
                history <= {train_history[30:0], train_taken};
            end else if (predict_valid) begin
                history <= {history[30:0], predict_taken};
            end
        end
    end

    assign predict_history = history;

endmodule

    input reset,
    output reg [3:0] q);

You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

A dual-edge triggered flip-flop is triggered on both edges of the clock. However, FPGAs don't have dual-edge triggered flip-flops, and always @(posedge clk or negedge clk) is not accepted as a legal sensitivity list. Build a circuit that functionally behaves like a dual-edge triggered flip-flop.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input d,
	output reg q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input d,
    output reg q);

    reg pos_q, neg_q;
    reg clken;

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (!clken) begin
            pos_q <= d;
        end
    end

    always @(negedge clk) begin
        if (clken) begin
            neg_q <= d;
        end
    end

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        clken <= ~clken;
    end

    always @(*) begin
        if (clken) begin
            q <= neg_q;
        end else begin
            q <= pos_q;
        end
    end

endmodule

	input clk,
	input load,
	input [1:0] ena,
	input [99:0] data,
	output reg [99:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input [1:0] ena,
    input [99:0] data,
    output reg [99:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else begin
            if (ena == 2'b01) begin // Rotate right
                q <= {q[0], q[99:1]};
            end else if (ena == 2'b10) begin // Rotate left
                q <= {q[98:0], q[99]};
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

    input clk,
    input reset,
    output reg [9:0] q);

	input in,
	input [9:0] state,
	output [9:0] next_state,
	output out1,
	output out2);

completion:
module top_module (
    input clk,
    input j,
    input k,
    output reg Q
);

always @(posedge clk) begin
    case ({j, k})
        2'b00: Q <= Q;       // No change
        2'b01: Q <= 0;       // Reset
        2'b10: Q <= 1;       // Set
        2'b11: Q <= ~Q;      // Toggle
    endcase
end

endmodule

You may choose to use an `assign` statement to drive each of the output wires, or you may choose to declare (four) wires for use as intermediate signals, where each internal wire is driven by the output of one of the AND gates.

// In this circuit, p1y should be the OR of two 3-input AND gates: one that ANDs p1a, p1b, and p1c, and the second that ANDs p1d, p1e, and p1f. The output p2y is the OR of two 2-input AND gates: one that ANDs p2a and p2b, and the second that ANDs p2c and p2d.

    input p1f,

    input p2a,
    input p2b,
    input p2c,

);

    assign p2y = (p2a & p2b) | (p2c & p2d);

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

This combinational circuit is supposed to recognize 8-bit keyboard scancodes for keys 0 through 9. It should indicate whether one of the 10 cases were recognized (valid), and if so, which key was detected. If the 8-bit input is 8'h45, 8'h16, 8'h1e, 8'h26, 8'h25, 8'h2e, 8'h36, 8'h3d, 8'h3e, or 8'h46, the 4-bit output will be set to 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9 respectively, the 1-bit valid would be set to 1. If the input does not match any of the cases, both output signals would be set to 0.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
completion:
module top_module (
    input [7:0] code,
    output reg [3:0] out,
    output reg valid
);

    always @(*) begin
        valid = 0;
        out = 0;
        case (code)
            8'h45: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 1; end
            8'h16: begin out = 4'h1; valid = 1; end
            8'h1e: begin out = 4'h2; valid = 1; end
            8'h26: begin out = 4'h3; valid = 1; end
            8'h25: begin out = 4'h4; valid = 1; end
            8'h2e: begin out = 4'h5; valid = 1; end
            8'h36: begin out = 4'h6; valid = 1; end
            8'h3d: begin out = 4'h7; valid = 1; end
            8'h3e: begin out = 4'h8; valid = 1; end
            8'h46: begin out = 4'h9; valid = 1; end
            default: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 0; end
        endcase
    end

endmodule

Build a four-bit shift register that also acts as a down counter. Data is shifted in most-significant-bit first when shift_ena is 1. The number currently in the shift register is decremented when count_ena is 1. Since the full system doesn't ever use shift_ena and count_ena together, it does not matter what your circuit does if both control inputs are 1 (This mainly means that it doesn't matter which case gets higher priority).
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input shift_ena,
	input count_ena,
	input data,
	output reg [3:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input shift_ena,
    input count_ena,
    input data,
    output reg [3:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (shift_ena) begin
            q[3:1] <= q[2:0];
            q[0] <= data;
        end else if (count_ena) begin
            q <= q - 1;
        end
    end

endmodule

Consider a finite state machine that is used to control some type of motor. The FSM has inputs x and y, which come from the motor, and produces outputs f and g, which control the motor. There is also a clock input called clk and a reset input (synchronous, active low) called resetn. The FSM has to work as follows. As long as the reset input is asserted, the FSM stays in a beginning state, called state A. When the reset signal is de-asserted, then after the next clock edge the FSM has to set the output f to 1 for one clock cycle. Then, the FSM has to monitor the x input. When x has produced the values 1, 0, 1 in three successive clock cycles, then g should be set to 1 on the following clock cycle. While maintaining g = 1 the FSM has to monitor the y input. If y has the value 1 within at most two clock cycles, then the FSM should maintain g = 1 permanently (that is, until reset). But if y does not become 1 within two clock cycles, then the FSM should set g = 0 permanently (until reset).
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

	input clk,
	input resetn,
	input x,

	output g
);

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Parity checking is often used as a simple method of detecting errors when transmitting data through an imperfect channel. Create a circuit that will compute a parity bit for a 8-bit byte (which will add a 9th bit to the byte). We will use "even" parity, where the parity bit is just the XOR of all 8 data bits.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

completion:
module top_module (
    input in,
    input [1:0] state,
    output reg [1:0] next_state,
    output out
);

    always @(*) begin
        case (state)
            2'b00: next_state = in ? 2'b01 : 2'b00; // A
            2'b01: next_state = in ? 2'b01 : 2'b10; // B
            2'b10: next_state = in ? 2'b11 : 2'b00; // C
            2'b11: next_state = in ? 2'b01 : 2'b10; // D
            default: next_state = 2'b00;
        endcase
    end

    assign out = (state == 2'b11); // D
endmodule

Create 16 D flip-flops. It's sometimes useful to only modify parts of a group of flip-flops. The byte-enable inputs control whether each byte of the 16 registers should be written to on that cycle. byteena[1] controls the upper byte d[15:8], while byteena[0] controls the lower byte d[7:0]. resetn is a synchronous, active-low reset. All DFFs should be triggered by the positive edge of clk.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input resetn,
	input [1:0] byteena,
	input [15:0] d,
	output reg [15:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input resetn,
    input [1:0] byteena,
    input [15:0] d,
    output reg [15:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (!resetn) begin
            q <= 16'b0;
        end else begin
            if (byteena[0]) begin
                q[7:0] <= d[7:0];
            end
            if (byteena[1]) begin
                q[15:8] <= d[15:8];
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

For each bit in an 8-bit vector, detect when the input signal changes from 0 in one clock cycle to 1 the next (similar to positive edge detection). The output bit should be set the cycle after a 0 to 1 transition occurs.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input [7:0] in,
	output reg [7:0] pedge);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input [7:0] in,
    output reg [7:0] pedge);

  reg [7:0] prev_in;

  always @(posedge clk) begin
    prev_in <= in;
    pedge <= {8{1'b0}}; // Default to 0
    for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++) begin
      if (!prev_in[i] && in[i]) begin
        pedge[i] <= 1'b1;
      end
    end
  end

endmodule

module top_module (
    input clock,
    input a,
    output reg p,
    output reg q
);

    always @(posedge clock or negedge clock) begin
        if (posedge clock) begin
            if (!a) begin
                p <= 0;
                q <= 0;
            end
        end else begin
            if (a) begin
                p <= 1;
            end
            if (p) begin
                q <= 1;
            end else if (!a) begin
                q <= 0;
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input load,
	input [511:0] data,
	output reg [511:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input [511:0] data,
    output reg [511:0] q);

    reg [511:0] next_q;

    always @(*) begin
        for (int i = 0; i < 512; i++) begin
            if (i == 0) begin
                next_q[i] = 1'b0 ^ q[i+1];
            end else if (i == 511) begin
                next_q[i] = q[i-1] ^ 1'b0;
            end else begin
                next_q[i] = q[i-1] ^ q[i+1];
            end
        end
    end

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else begin
            q <= next_q;
        end
    end

endmodule

In many (older) serial communications protocols, each data byte is sent along with a start bit and a stop bit, to help the receiver delimit bytes from the stream of bits. One common scheme is to use one start bit (0), 8 data bits, and 1 stop bit (1). The line is also at logic 1 when nothing is being transmitted (idle). Design a finite state machine that will identify when bytes have been correctly received when given a stream of bits. It needs to identify the start bit, wait for all 8 data bits, then verify that the stop bit was correct. If the stop bit does not appear when expected, the FSM must wait until it finds a stop bit before attempting to receive the next byte. Include a active-high synchronous reset. Note that the serial protocol sends the least significant bit first.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input ena,
    input [1:0] amount,
    input [63:0] data,
    output reg [63:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else if (ena) begin
            case (amount)
                2'b00: q <= {q[62:0], 1'b0}; // Shift Left by 1
                2'b01: q <= {q[55:0], 8'b0}; // Shift Left by 8
                2'b10: q <= {q[63], q[63:1]}; // Arithmetic Shift Right by 1
                2'b11: q <= { {8{q[63]}}, q[63:8]}; // Arithmetic Shift Right by 8
                default: q <= q; // No shift
            endcase
        end
    end

endmodule

You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

For each bit in a 32-bit vector, capture when the input signal changes from 1 in one clock cycle to 0 the next. "Capture" means that the output will remain 1 until the register is reset (active high synchronous reset).
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input [31:0] in,
	output reg [31:0] out);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input reset,
    input [31:0] in,
    output reg [31:0] out);

    reg [31:0] prev_in;

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (reset) begin
            out <= 0;
        end else begin
            for (int i = 0; i < 32; i++) begin
                if (prev_in[i] == 1 && in[i] == 0) begin
                    out[i] <= 1;
                end
            end
        end
        prev_in <= in;
    end

endmodule

Build a two-bit saturating counter. The counter increments (up to a maximum of 3) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 1. It decrements (down to a minimum of 0) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 0. When not training (train_valid = 0), the counter keeps its value unchanged. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the counter to weakly not-taken (2'b01). Output state[1:0] is the two-bit counter value.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);

    always_ff @(posedge clk, posedge areset) begin
        if (areset) begin
            state <= 2'b01;
        end else begin
            if (train_valid) begin
                if (train_taken) begin
                    if (state < 2'b11) begin
                        state <= state + 1;
                    end
                end else begin
                    if (state > 2'b00) begin
                        state <= state - 1;
                    end
                end
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

    input clk,
    input [7:0] in,
    output reg [7:0] anyedge);

    reg [7:0] prev_in;

        anyedge <= 0; // Reset every clock cycle

                anyedge[i] <= 1;
            end

    end

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

This combinational circuit is supposed to recognize 8-bit keyboard scancodes for keys 0 through 9. It should indicate whether one of the 10 cases were recognized (valid), and if so, which key was detected. If the 8-bit input is 8'h45, 8'h16, 8'h1e, 8'h26, 8'h25, 8'h2e, 8'h36, 8'h3d, 8'h3e, or 8'h46, the 4-bit output will be set to 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9 respectively, the 1-bit valid would be set to 1. If the input does not match any of the cases, both output signals would be set to 0.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
completion:
module top_module (
    input [7:0] code,
    output reg [3:0] out,
    output reg valid
);

    always @(*) begin
        valid = 0;
        out = 0;
        case (code)
            8'h45: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 1; end
            8'h16: begin out = 4'h1; valid = 1; end
            8'h1e: begin out = 4'h2; valid = 1; end
            8'h26: begin out = 4'h3; valid = 1; end
            8'h25: begin out = 4'h4; valid = 1; end
            8'h2e: begin out = 4'h5; valid = 1; end
            8'h36: begin out = 4'h6; valid = 1; end
            8'h3d: begin out = 4'h7; valid = 1; end
            8'h3e: begin out = 4'h8; valid = 1; end
            8'h46: begin out = 4'h9; valid = 1; end
            default: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 0; end
        endcase
    end

endmodule

Consider a finite state machine that is used to control some type of motor. The FSM has inputs x and y, which come from the motor, and produces outputs f and g, which control the motor. There is also a clock input called clk and a reset input (synchronous, active low) called resetn. The FSM has to work as follows. As long as the reset input is asserted, the FSM stays in a beginning state, called state A. When the reset signal is de-asserted, then after the next clock edge the FSM has to set the output f to 1 for one clock cycle. Then, the FSM has to monitor the x input. When x has produced the values 1, 0, 1 in three successive clock cycles, then g should be set to 1 on the following clock cycle. While maintaining g = 1 the FSM has to monitor the y input. If y has the value 1 within at most two clock cycles, then the FSM should maintain g = 1 permanently (that is, until reset). But if y does not become 1 within two clock cycles, then the FSM should set g = 0 permanently (until reset).

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Parity checking is often used as a simple method of detecting errors when transmitting data through an imperfect channel. Create a circuit that will compute a parity bit for a 8-bit byte (which will add a 9th bit to the byte). We will use "even" parity, where the parity bit is just the XOR of all 8 data bits.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

completion:
module top_module (
    input in,
    input [1:0] state,
    output reg [1:0] next_state,
    output out
);

    always @(*) begin
        case (state)
            2'b00: begin // State A
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b00; // A
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            2'b01: begin // State B
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b10; // C
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            2'b10: begin // State C
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b00; // A
                else next_state = 2'b11; // D
            end
            2'b11: begin // State D
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b10; // C
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            default: next_state = 2'b00; // Default to state A
        endcase
    end

    assign out = (state == 2'b11) ? 1 : 0; // Output is 1 only in state D
endmodule

Consider a finite state machine with inputs s and w. Assume that the FSM begins in a reset state called A, as depicted below. The FSM remains in state A as long as s = 0, and it moves to state B when s = 1. Once in state B the FSM examines the value of the input w in the next three clock cycles. If w = 1 in exactly two of these clock cycles, then the FSM has to set an output z to 1 in the following clock cycle. Otherwise z has to be 0. The FSM continues checking w for the next three clock cycles, and so on. Use as few states as possible. Note that the s input is used only in state A, so you need to consider just the w input. Assume reset is active high synchronous.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module (
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input s,
	input w,
	output reg z
);

Implement in Verilog the following circuit: A D flip-flop takes as input the output of a two-input XOR. The flip-flop is positive edge triggered by clk, but there is no reset. The XOR takes as input 'in' along with the output 'out' of the flip-flop.

```verilog

prompt:

	input clk,
	input areset,
	input load,
	input ena,
	input [3:0] data,
	output reg [3:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input load,
    input ena,
    input [3:0] data,
    output reg [3:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk or posedge areset) begin
        if (areset) begin
            q <= 4'b0000;
        end else begin
            if (load) begin
                q <= data;
            end else if (ena) begin
                q <= {1'b0, q[3:1]};
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

In many (older) serial communications protocols, each data byte is sent along with a start bit and a stop bit, to help the receiver delimit bytes from the stream of bits. One common scheme is to use one start bit (0), 8 data bits, and 1 stop bit (1). The line is also at logic 1 when nothing is being transmitted (idle). Design a finite state machine that will identify when bytes have been correctly received when given a stream of bits. It needs to identify the start bit, wait for all 8 data bits, then verify that the stop bit was correct. If the stop bit does not appear when expected, the FSM must wait until it finds a stop bit before attempting to receive the next byte. Include a active-high synchronous reset. Note that the serial protocol sends the least significant bit first.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

    input clk,
    input load,
    input ena,
    input [1:0] amount,
    input [63:0] data,
    output reg [63:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else if (ena) begin
            case (amount)
                2'b00: q <= {q[62:0], 1'b0};          // Shift Left by 1
                2'b01: q <= {q[55:0], 8'b0};          // Shift Left by 8
                2'b10: q <= {q[63], q[63:1]};        // Arithmetic Shift Right by 1
                2'b11: q <= { {8{q[63]}}, q[63:8]}; // Arithmetic Shift Right by 8
                default: q <= q;
            endcase
        end
    end

endmodule

completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input [511:0] data,
    output reg [511:0] q);

    reg [511:0] next_q;

    always @(*) begin
        for (int i = 0; i < 512; i++) begin
            // Rule 110 implementation
            next_q[i] = (
                ((i > 0) ? q[i-1] : 0) & q[i] & ((i < 511) ? ~q[i+1] : 1) ) |
                (((i > 0) ? q[i-1] : 0) & ~q[i] & ((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 0) ) |
                ((~(i > 0) ? 1 : ~q[i-1]) & q[i] & ((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 0) ) |
                ((~(i > 0) ? 1 : ~q[i-1]) & ~q[i] & ((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 0) );
        end
    end

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else begin
            q <= next_q;
        end
    end

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

For each bit in a 32-bit vector, capture when the input signal changes from 1 in one clock cycle to 0 the next. "Capture" means that the output will remain 1 until the register is reset (active high synchronous reset).
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input [31:0] in,
	output reg [31:0] out);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input reset,
    input [31:0] in,
    output reg [31:0] out);

    reg [31:0] in_prev;

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (reset) begin
            out <= 0;
        end else begin
            for (int i = 0; i < 32; i++) begin
                if (in_prev[i] == 1 && in[i] == 0) begin
                    out[i] <= 1;
                end
            end
        end
        in_prev <= in;
    end

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Build a two-bit saturating counter. The counter increments (up to a maximum of 3) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 1. It decrements (down to a minimum of 0) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 0. When not training (train_valid = 0), the counter keeps its value unchanged. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the counter to weakly not-taken (2'b01). Output state[1:0] is the two-bit counter value.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);

    always_ff @(posedge clk, posedge areset) begin
        if (areset) begin
            state <= 2'b01;
        end else begin
            if (train_valid) begin
                if (train_taken) begin
                    if (state < 2'b11) begin
                        state <= state + 1;
                    end
                end else begin
                    if (state > 2'b00) begin
                        state <= state - 1;
                    end
                end
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

    input [15:0] scancode,
    output reg left,
    output reg down,
    output reg right,
    output reg up
);

    always @(*) begin
        case (scancode)
            16'he06b: begin left = 1; down = 0; right = 0; up = 0; end
            16'he072: begin left = 0; down = 1; right = 0; up = 0; end
            16'he074: begin left = 0; down = 0; right = 1; up = 0; end
            16'he075: begin left = 0; down = 0; right = 0; up = 1; end
            default:  begin left = 0; down = 0; right = 0; up = 0; end

    end

endmodule

    output reg [31:0] q);

            q <= 32'h1;
        end else begin
            q <= {q[30:0], q[31] ^ q[21] ^ q[1] ^ q[0]};

A linear feedback shift register is a shift register usually with a few XOR gates to produce the next state of the shift register. A Galois LFSR is one particular arrangement where bit positions with a "tap" are XORed with the output bit to produce its next value, while bit positions without a tap shift. If the taps positions are carefully chosen, the LFSR can be made to be "maximum-length". A maximum-length LFSR of n bits cycles through 2**n-1 states before repeating (the all-zero state is never reached). Build a 5-bit maximal-length Galois LFSR with taps at bit positions 5 and 3. description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

This combinational circuit is supposed to recognize 8-bit keyboard scancodes for keys 0 through 9. It should indicate whether one of the 10 cases were recognized (valid), and if so, which key was detected. If the 8-bit input is 8'h45, 8'h16, 8'h1e, 8'h26, 8'h25, 8'h2e, 8'h36, 8'h3d, 8'h3e, or 8'h46, the 4-bit output will be set to 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9 respectively, the 1-bit valid would be set to 1. If the input does not match any of the cases, both output signals would be set to 0.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
completion:
module top_module (
    input [7:0] code,
    output reg [3:0] out,
    output reg valid
);

    always @(*) begin
        valid = 0;
        out = 0;
        case (code)
            8'h45: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 1; end
            8'h16: begin out = 4'h1; valid = 1; end
            8'h1e: begin out = 4'h2; valid = 1; end
            8'h26: begin out = 4'h3; valid = 1; end
            8'h25: begin out = 4'h4; valid = 1; end
            8'h2e: begin out = 4'h5; valid = 1; end
            8'h36: begin out = 4'h6; valid = 1; end
            8'h3d: begin out = 4'h7; valid = 1; end
            8'h3e: begin out = 4'h8; valid = 1; end
            8'h46: begin out = 4'h9; valid = 1; end
            default: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 0; end
        endcase
    end

endmodule

As long as the reset input is asserted, the FSM stays in a beginning state, called state A. When the reset signal is de-asserted, then after the next clock edge the FSM has to set the output f to 1 for one clock cycle. Then, the FSM has to monitor the x input. When x has produced the values 1, 0, 1 in three successive clock cycles, then g should be set to 1 on the following clock cycle. While maintaining g = 1 the FSM has to monitor the y input. If y has the value 1 within at most two clock cycles, then the FSM should maintain g = 1 permanently (that is, until reset). Parity checking is often used as a simple method of detecting errors when transmitting data through an imperfect channel. Create a circuit that will compute a parity bit for a 8-bit byte (which will add a 9th bit to the byte). We will use "even" parity, where the parity bit is just the XOR of all 8 data bits.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

completion:
module top_module (
    input in,
    input [1:0] state,
    output reg [1:0] next_state,
    output out
);

    always @(*) begin
        case (state)
            2'b00: next_state = in ? 2'b01 : 2'b00; // A
            2'b01: next_state = in ? 2'b01 : 2'b10; // B
            2'b10: next_state = in ? 2'b11 : 2'b00; // C
            2'b11: next_state = in ? 2'b01 : 2'b10; // D
            default: next_state = 2'b00;
        endcase
    end

    assign out = (state == 2'b11); // D
endmodule

In many (older) serial communications protocols, each data byte is sent along with a start bit and a stop bit, to help the receiver delimit bytes from the stream of bits. One common scheme is to use one start bit (0), 8 data bits, and 1 stop bit (1). The line is also at logic 1 when nothing is being transmitted (idle). Note that the serial protocol sends the least significant bit first.

module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input ena,
    input [1:0] amount,
    input [63:0] data,
    output reg [63:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else if (ena) begin
            case (amount)
                2'b00: q <= {q[62:0], 1'b0}; // Shift left by 1
                2'b01: q <= {q[55:0], 8'b0}; // Shift left by 8
                2'b10: q <= {q[63], q[63:1]}; // Shift right by 1 (arithmetic)
                2'b11: q <= { {8{q[63]}}, q[63:8]}; // Shift right by 8 (arithmetic)
                default: q <= q; // No shift
            endcase
        end
    end
endmodule

completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input [511:0] data,
    output reg [511:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else begin
            reg [511:0] next_q;
            integer i;
            for (i = 0; i < 512; i = i + 1) begin
                // Rule 110 implementation
                next_q[i] <= (~(q[i-1:i-1] & q[i] & q[i+1:i+1]) ) &
                            ( (q[i-1:i-1] & q[i] & ~q[i+1:i+1]) |
                              (q[i-1:i-1] & ~q[i] & q[i+1:i+1]) |
                              (~q[i-1:i-1] & q[i] & q[i+1:i+1]) |
                              (~q[i-1:i-1] & q[i] & ~q[i+1:i+1]) |
                              (~q[i-1:i-1] & ~q[i] & q[i+1:i+1]) );
            end

            // Handle boundary conditions (q[-1] = 0 and q[512] = 0)
            next_q[0] <= (~(0 & q[0] & q[1]) ) &
                            ( (0 & q[0] & ~q[1]) |
                              (0 & ~q[0] & q[1]) |
                              (~0 & q[0] & q[1]) |
                              (~0 & q[0] & ~q[1]) |
                              (~0 & ~q[0] & q[1]) );

            next_q[511] <= (~(q[510] & q[511] & 0) ) &
                            ( (q[510] & q[511] & ~0) |
                              (q[510] & ~q[511] & 0) |
                              (~q[510] & q[511] & 0) |
                              (~q[510] & q[511] & ~0) |
                              (~q[510] & ~q[511] & 0) );

            q <= next_q;
        end
    end

endmodule

    input clk,
    input reset,
    input [31:0] in,
    output reg [31:0] out);

    reg [31:0] in_prev;

    always @(posedge clk) begin

            out <= 0;

                if (in_prev[i] == 1 && in[i] == 0) begin

endmodule

It decrements (down to a minimum of 0) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 0. When not training (train_valid = 0), the counter keeps its value unchanged. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the counter to weakly not-taken (2'b01). Output state[1:0] is the two-bit counter value.

);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);

    always_ff @(posedge clk, posedge areset) begin
        if (areset) begin
            state <= 2'b01;
        end else begin
            if (train_valid) begin
                if (train_taken) begin
                    if (state < 2'b11) begin
                        state <= state + 1;
                    end
                end else begin
                    if (state > 2'b00) begin
                        state <= state - 1;
                    end
                end
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

A Galois LFSR is one particular arrangement where bit positions with a "tap" are XORed with the output bit to produce each bit's next value, while bit positions without a tap shift. Build a 32-bit Galois LFSR with taps at bit positions 32, 22, 2, and 1. Reset should be active high synchronous, and should reset the output q to 32'h1.

	input reset,

    input clk,
    input reset,
    output reg [31:0] q);

        if (reset) begin
            q <= 32'h1;
        end else begin
            q <= {q[30:0], q[31] ^ q[21] ^ q[1] ^ q[0]};
        end
    end

Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:

	input x,
	input y,
	output z);

module top_module(
	input clk,
	input load,
	input [1:0] ena,
	input [99:0] data,
	output reg [99:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input [1:0] ena,
    input [99:0] data,
    output reg [99:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else begin
            case (ena)
                2'b01: begin // Rotate right
                    q <= {q[0], q[99:1]};
                end
                2'b10: begin // Rotate left
                    q <= {q[98:0], q[99]};
                end
                default: begin // No rotate
                    q <= q;
                end
            endcase
        end
    end
endmodule

This combinational circuit is supposed to recognize 8-bit keyboard scancodes for keys 0 through 9. It should indicate whether one of the 10 cases were recognized (valid), and if so, which key was detected. If the 8-bit input is 8'h45, 8'h16, 8'h1e, 8'h26, 8'h25, 8'h2e, 8'h36, 8'h3d, 8'h3e, or 8'h46, the 4-bit output will be set to 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9 respectively, the 1-bit valid would be set to 1. If the input does not match any of the cases, both output signals would be set to 0.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
completion:
module top_module (
    input [7:0] code,
    output reg [3:0] out,
    output reg valid
);

    always @(*) begin
        valid = 0;
        out = 0;
        case (code)
            8'h45: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 1; end
            8'h16: begin out = 4'h1; valid = 1; end
            8'h1e: begin out = 4'h2; valid = 1; end
            8'h26: begin out = 4'h3; valid = 1; end
            8'h25: begin out = 4'h4; valid = 1; end
            8'h2e: begin out = 4'h5; valid = 1; end
            8'h36: begin out = 4'h6; valid = 1; end
            8'h3d: begin out = 4'h7; valid = 1; end
            8'h3e: begin out = 4'h8; valid = 1; end
            8'h46: begin out = 4'h9; valid = 1; end
            default: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 0; end
        endcase
    end

endmodule

Consider a finite state machine that is used to control some type of motor. The FSM has inputs x and y, which come from the motor, and produces outputs f and g, which control the motor. There is also a clock input called clk and a reset input (synchronous, active low) called resetn. The FSM has to work as follows. As long as the reset input is asserted, the FSM stays in a beginning state, called state A. When the reset signal is de-asserted, then after the next clock edge the FSM has to set the output f to 1 for one clock cycle. Then, the FSM has to monitor the x input. When x has produced the values 1, 0, 1 in three successive clock cycles, then g should be set to 1 on the following clock cycle. While maintaining g = 1 the FSM has to monitor the y input. If y has the value 1 within at most two clock cycles, then the FSM should maintain g = 1 permanently (that is, until reset). But if y does not become 1 within two clock cycles, then the FSM should set g = 0 permanently (until reset).

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Parity checking is often used as a simple method of detecting errors when transmitting data through an imperfect channel. Create a circuit that will compute a parity bit for a 8-bit byte (which will add a 9th bit to the byte). We will use "even" parity, where the parity bit is just the XOR of all 8 data bits.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

completion:
module top_module (
    input in,
    input [1:0] state,
    output reg [1:0] next_state,
    output out
);

    always @(*) begin
        case (state)
            2'b00: next_state = in ? 2'b01 : 2'b00; // A
            2'b01: next_state = in ? 2'b01 : 2'b10; // B
            2'b10: next_state = in ? 2'b11 : 2'b00; // C
            2'b11: next_state = in ? 2'b01 : 2'b10; // D
            default: next_state = 2'b00;
        endcase
    end

    assign out = (state == 2'b11) ? 1'b1 : 1'b0; // Output is 1 only in state D
endmodule

    input clk,
    input [7:0] in,
    output reg [7:0] pedge);

    input [3:0] state,
    output reg [3:0] next_state,
    output out
);

    always @(*) begin
        next_state[0] = (~in) & (state[0] | state[2]);  // A_next
        next_state[1] = (in) & (state[0] | state[1] | state[3]);  // B_next
        next_state[2] = (~in) & (state[1] | state[3]);  // C_next
        next_state[3] = (in) & (state[2]);  // D_next
    end

    assign out = state[3];  // Output is D

endmodule

completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input ena,
    input [1:0] amount,
    input [63:0] data,
    output reg [63:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else if (ena) begin
            case (amount)
                2'b00: q <= {q[62:0], 1'b0};          // Shift Left by 1
                2'b01: q <= {q[55:0], 8'b0};          // Shift Left by 8
                2'b10: q <= {q[63], q[63:1]};        // Arithmetic Shift Right by 1
                2'b11: q <= { {8{q[63]}}, q[63:8]};  // Arithmetic Shift Right by 8
                default: q <= q;
            endcase
        end
    end

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

For each bit in a 32-bit vector, capture when the input signal changes from 1 in one clock cycle to 0 the next. "Capture" means that the output will remain 1 until the register is reset (active high synchronous reset).
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input [31:0] in,
	output reg [31:0] out);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input reset,
    input [31:0] in,
    output reg [31:0] out);

    reg [31:0] in_prev;

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (reset) begin
            out <= 0;
        end else begin
            for (int i = 0; i < 32; i++) begin
                if (in_prev[i] == 1 && in[i] == 0) begin
                    out[i] <= 1;
                end
            end
        end
        in_prev <= in;
    end

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Build a two-bit saturating counter. The counter increments (up to a maximum of 3) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 1. It decrements (down to a minimum of 0) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 0. When not training (train_valid = 0), the counter keeps its value unchanged. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the counter to weakly not-taken (2'b01). Output state[1:0] is the two-bit counter value.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);

    always_ff @(posedge clk, posedge areset) begin
        if (areset) begin
            state <= 2'b01;
        end else begin
            if (train_valid) begin
                if (train_taken) begin
                    if (state < 2'b11) begin
                        state <= state + 1;
                    end
                end else begin
                    if (state > 2'b00) begin
                        state <= state - 1;
                    end
                end
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

    output reg down,
    output reg right,
    output reg up
);

            16'he06b: begin left = 1; down = 0; right = 0; up = 0; end
            16'he072: begin left = 0; down = 1; right = 0; up = 0; end

	input [99:0] data,
	output reg [99:0] q);

module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input [1:0] ena,
    input [99:0] data,
    output reg [99:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else begin
            case (ena)
                2'b01: begin // Rotate right
                    q <= {q[0], q[99:1]};
                end
                2'b10: begin // Rotate left
                    q <= {q[98:0], q[99]};
                end
                default: begin // No rotate
                    q <= q;
                end
            endcase
        end
    end

endmodule

This combinational circuit is supposed to recognize 8-bit keyboard scancodes for keys 0 through 9. It should indicate whether one of the 10 cases were recognized (valid), and if so, which key was detected. If the 8-bit input is 8'h45, 8'h16, 8'h1e, 8'h26, 8'h25, 8'h2e, 8'h36, 8'h3d, 8'h3e, or 8'h46, the 4-bit output will be set to 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9 respectively, the 1-bit valid would be set to 1. If the input does not match any of the cases, both output signals would be set to 0.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

module top_module (
    input [7:0] code,
    output reg [3:0] out,
    output reg valid
);

    always @(*) begin
        valid = 0;
        out = 0;
        case (code)
            8'h45: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 1; end
            8'h16: begin out = 4'h1; valid = 1; end
            8'h1e: begin out = 4'h2; valid = 1; end
            8'h26: begin out = 4'h3; valid = 1; end
            8'h25: begin out = 4'h4; valid = 1; end
            8'h2e: begin out = 4'h5; valid = 1; end
            8'h36: begin out = 4'h6; valid = 1; end
            8'h3d: begin out = 4'h7; valid = 1; end
            8'h3e: begin out = 4'h8; valid = 1; end
            8'h46: begin out = 4'h9; valid = 1; end
            default: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 0; end
        endcase
    end

endmodule

Consider a finite state machine that is used to control some type of motor. The FSM has inputs x and y, which come from the motor, and produces outputs f and g, which control the motor. There is also a clock input called clk and a reset input (synchronous, active low) called resetn. The FSM has to work as follows. As long as the reset input is asserted, the FSM stays in a beginning state, called state A. When the reset signal is de-asserted, then after the next clock edge the FSM has to set the output f to 1 for one clock cycle. Then, the FSM has to monitor the x input. When x has produced the values 1, 0, 1 in three successive clock cycles, then g should be set to 1 on the following clock cycle. While maintaining g = 1 the FSM has to monitor the y input. If y has the value 1 within at most two clock cycles, then the FSM should maintain g = 1 permanently (that is, until reset). But if y does not become 1 within two clock cycles, then the FSM should set g = 0 permanently (until reset).

You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Parity checking is often used as a simple method of detecting errors when transmitting data through an imperfect channel. Create a circuit that will compute a parity bit for a 8-bit byte (which will add a 9th bit to the byte). We will use "even" parity, where the parity bit is just the XOR of all 8 data bits.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

completion:
module top_module (
    input in,
    input [1:0] state,
    output reg [1:0] next_state,
    output out
);

    always @(*) begin
        case (state)
            2'b00: begin // State A
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b00; // A
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            2'b01: begin // State B
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b10; // C
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            2'b10: begin // State C
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b00; // A
                else next_state = 2'b11; // D
            end
            2'b11: begin // State D
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b10; // C
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            default: next_state = 2'b00; // Default to A
        endcase
    end

    assign out = (state == 2'b11) ? 1'b1 : 1'b0; // Output is 1 only in state D
endmodule

module top_module (
    input in,
    input [3:0] state,
    output reg [3:0] next_state,
    output out
);

    always @(*) begin
        next_state[0] = state[0] & ~in | state[2] & ~in;  // A_next
        next_state[1] = state[0] & in | state[1] & in | state[3] & in;  // B_next
        next_state[2] = state[1] & ~in | state[3] & ~in;  // C_next
        next_state[3] = state[2] & in;  // D_next
    end

    assign out = state[3];  // Output is high when in state D

endmodule

One common scheme is to use one start bit (0), 8 data bits, and 1 stop bit (1). The line is also at logic 1 when nothing is being transmitted (idle). Note that the serial protocol sends the least significant bit first.

        if (load) begin

            case (amount)
                2'b00: q <= {q[62:0], 1'b0};          // Shift Left by 1
                2'b01: q <= {q[55:0], 8'b0};          // Shift Left by 8
                2'b10: q <= {q[63], q[63:1]};        // Arithmetic Shift Right by 1
                2'b11: q <= { {8{q[63]}}, q[63:8]};  // Arithmetic Shift Right by 8
                default: q <= q;
            endcase
        end
    end

endmodule

Write a Verilog module named top_module for one stage of this circuit, including both the flip-flop and multiplexers.

prompt:

	input a,

	input clk,
	input load,

	output reg [511:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input [511:0] data,
    output reg [511:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else begin
            reg [511:0] next_q;
            integer i;
            for (i = 0; i < 512; i = i + 1) begin
                // Rule 110 implementation
                next_q[i] <= ( ( (i > 0) ? q[i-1] : 1'b0) & q[i] & ~((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 1'b0)) |
                             ( ( (i > 0) ? q[i-1] : 1'b0) & ~q[i] & ((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 1'b0)) |
                             ( ( (i > 0) ? q[i-1] : 1'b0) & ~q[i] & ~((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 1'b0)) |
                             ( ~((i > 0) ? q[i-1] : 1'b0) & q[i] & ((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 1'b0)) |
                             ( ~((i > 0) ? q[i-1] : 1'b0) & q[i] & ~((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 1'b0)) |
                             ( ~((i > 0) ? q[i-1] : 1'b0) & ~q[i] & ((i < 511) ? q[i+1] : 1'b0));
            end
            q <= next_q;
        end
    end
endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

For each bit in a 32-bit vector, capture when the input signal changes from 1 in one clock cycle to 0 the next. "Capture" means that the output will remain 1 until the register is reset (active high synchronous reset).
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input [31:0] in,
	output reg [31:0] out);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input reset,
    input [31:0] in,
    output reg [31:0] out);

    reg [31:0] in_prev;

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (reset) begin
            out <= 0;
        end else begin
            for (int i = 0; i < 32; i++) begin
                if (in_prev[i] == 1 && in[i] == 0) begin
                    out[i] <= 1;
                end
            end
        end
        in_prev <= in;
    end

endmodule

Build a two-bit saturating counter. The counter increments (up to a maximum of 3) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 1. It decrements (down to a minimum of 0) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 0. When not training (train_valid = 0), the counter keeps its value unchanged. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the counter to weakly not-taken (2'b01). Output state[1:0] is the two-bit counter value.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);

    always_ff @(posedge clk, posedge areset) begin
        if (areset) begin
            state <= 2'b01;
        end else begin
            if (train_valid) begin
                if (train_taken) begin
                    if (state < 2'b11) begin
                        state <= state + 1;
                    end
                end else begin
                    if (state > 2'b00) begin
                        state <= state - 1;
                    end
                end
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

            q <= data;

    end

You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

This combinational circuit is supposed to recognize 8-bit keyboard scancodes for keys 0 through 9. It should indicate whether one of the 10 cases were recognized (valid), and if so, which key was detected. If the 8-bit input is 8'h45, 8'h16, 8'h1e, 8'h26, 8'h25, 8'h2e, 8'h36, 8'h3d, 8'h3e, or 8'h46, the 4-bit output will be set to 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9 respectively, the 1-bit valid would be set to 1. If the input does not match any of the cases, both output signals would be set to 0.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
completion:
module top_module (
    input [7:0] code,
    output reg [3:0] out,
    output reg valid
);

    always @(*) begin
        valid = 0;
        out = 0;
        case (code)
            8'h45: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 1; end
            8'h16: begin out = 4'h1; valid = 1; end
            8'h1e: begin out = 4'h2; valid = 1; end
            8'h26: begin out = 4'h3; valid = 1; end
            8'h25: begin out = 4'h4; valid = 1; end
            8'h2e: begin out = 4'h5; valid = 1; end
            8'h36: begin out = 4'h6; valid = 1; end
            8'h3d: begin out = 4'h7; valid = 1; end
            8'h3e: begin out = 4'h8; valid = 1; end
            8'h46: begin out = 4'h9; valid = 1; end
            default: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 0; end
        endcase
    end

endmodule

When x has produced the values 1, 0, 1 in three successive clock cycles, then g should be set to 1 on the following clock cycle. While maintaining g = 1 the FSM has to monitor the y input. If y has the value 1 within at most two clock cycles, then the FSM should maintain g = 1 permanently (that is, until reset). description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Parity checking is often used as a simple method of detecting errors when transmitting data through an imperfect channel. Create a circuit that will compute a parity bit for a 8-bit byte (which will add a 9th bit to the byte). We will use "even" parity, where the parity bit is just the XOR of all 8 data bits.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

completion:
module top_module (
    input in,
    input [1:0] state,
    output reg [1:0] next_state,
    output out
);

    always @(*) begin
        case (state)
            2'b00: begin // State A
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b00; // A
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            2'b01: begin // State B
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b10; // C
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            2'b10: begin // State C
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b00; // A
                else next_state = 2'b11; // D
            end
            2'b11: begin // State D
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b10; // C
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            default: next_state = 2'b00; // Default to A
        endcase
    end

    assign out = (state == 2'b11) ? 1'b1 : 1'b0; // Output is 1 only in state D
endmodule

For each bit in a 32-bit vector, capture when the input signal changes from 1 in one clock cycle to 0 the next. "Capture" means that the output will remain 1 until the register is reset (active high synchronous reset).
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

	input clk,
	input reset,
	input [31:0] in,
	output reg [31:0] out);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input reset,
    input [31:0] in,
    output reg [31:0] out);

    reg [31:0] prev_in;

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (reset) begin
            out <= 32'b0;
        end else begin
            for (int i = 0; i < 32; i++) begin
                if (prev_in[i] == 1 && in[i] == 0) begin
                    out[i] <= 1;
                end
            end
        end
        prev_in <= in;
    end

endmodule

Build a two-bit saturating counter. The counter increments (up to a maximum of 3) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 1. It decrements (down to a minimum of 0) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 0. When not training (train_valid = 0), the counter keeps its value unchanged. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the counter to weakly not-taken (2'b01). Output state[1:0] is the two-bit counter value.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);

    always_ff @(posedge clk, posedge areset) begin
        if (areset) begin
            state <= 2'b01;
        end else begin
            if (train_valid) begin
                if (train_taken) begin
                    if (state < 2'b11) begin
                        state <= state + 1;
                    end
                end else begin
                    if (state > 2'b00) begin
                        state <= state - 1;
                    end
                end
            end
        end
    end

endmodule

Build a priority encoder for 8-bit inputs. Given an 8-bit vector, the output should report the first (least significant) bit in the vector that is 1. Report zero if the input vector has no bits that are high. For example, the input 8'b10010000 should output 3'd4, because bit[4] is first bit that is high.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

prompt:
module top_module (
	input [15:0] scancode,
	output reg left,
	output reg down,
	output reg right,
	output reg up
);
completion:
module top_module (
    input [15:0] scancode,
    output reg left,
    output reg down,
    output reg right,
    output reg up
);

    always @(*) begin
        case (scancode)
            16'he06b: begin left = 1; down = 0; right = 0; up = 0; end
            16'he072: begin left = 0; down = 1; right = 0; up = 0; end
            16'he074: begin left = 0; down = 0; right = 1; up = 0; end
            16'he075: begin left = 0; down = 0; right = 0; up = 1; end
            default:  begin left = 0; down = 0; right = 0; up = 0; end
        endcase
    end

endmodule

You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Build a 32-bit global history shift register, including support for rolling back state in response to a pipeline flush caused by a branch misprediction. When a branch prediction is made (predict_valid = 1), shift in predict_taken from the LSB side to update the branch history for the predicted branch. (predict_history[0] is the direction of the youngest branch.) When a branch misprediction occurs (train_mispredicted = 1), load the branch history register with the history after the completion of the mispredicted branch. This is the history before the mispredicted branch (train_history) concatenated with the actual result of the branch (train_taken). If both a prediction and misprediction occur at the same time, the misprediction takes precedence, because the pipeline flush will also flush out the branch that is currently making a prediction. predict_history is the value of the branch history register. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the history counter to zero.


Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:

(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input predict_valid,
    input predict_taken,
    output logic [31:0] predict_history,
    
    input train_mispredicted,
    input train_taken,
    input [31:0] train_history
);

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

A linear feedback shift register is a shift register usually with a few XOR gates to produce the next state of the shift register. A Galois LFSR is one particular arrangement where bit positions with a "tap" are XORed with the output bit to produce each bit's next value, while bit positions without a tap shift. Build a 32-bit Galois LFSR with taps at bit positions 32, 22, 2, and 1. Reset should be active high synchronous, and should reset the output q to 32'h1.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	output reg [31:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input reset,
    output reg [31:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (reset) begin
            q <= 32'h1;
        end else begin
            q <= {q[30:0], q[31] ^ q[21] ^ q[1] ^ q[0]};
        end
    end

endmodule

            end else begin

endmodule

You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Create a module that implements an XNOR gate.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

prompt:
module top_module(
	input x,
	input y,
	output z);

module top_module(
	input clk,
	input load,
	input [1:0] ena,
	input [99:0] data,
	output reg [99:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input [1:0] ena,
    input [99:0] data,
    output reg [99:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else begin
            case (ena)
                2'b01: begin // Rotate right
                    q <= {q[0], q[99:1]};
                end
                2'b10: begin // Rotate left
                    q <= {q[98:0], q[99]};
                end
                default: begin // No rotate
                    q <= q;
                end
            endcase
        end
    end

endmodule

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

This combinational circuit is supposed to recognize 8-bit keyboard scancodes for keys 0 through 9. It should indicate whether one of the 10 cases were recognized (valid), and if so, which key was detected. If the 8-bit input is 8'h45, 8'h16, 8'h1e, 8'h26, 8'h25, 8'h2e, 8'h36, 8'h3d, 8'h3e, or 8'h46, the 4-bit output will be set to 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9 respectively, the 1-bit valid would be set to 1. If the input does not match any of the cases, both output signals would be set to 0.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog
completion:
module top_module (
    input [7:0] code,
    output reg [3:0] out,
    output reg valid
);

    always @(*) begin
        valid = 0;
        out = 0;
        case (code)
            8'h45: begin out = 4'h0; valid = 1; end
            8'h16: begin out = 4'h1; valid = 1; end

    input clk,
    input shift_ena,
    input count_ena,
    input data,
    output reg [3:0] q);

            q[3:1] <= q[2:0];
            q[0] <= data;
        end else if (count_ena) begin
            q <= q - 1;
        end
    end

endmodule

The only indication is that the first byte of each three byte message always has in[3]=1 (but in[3] of the other two bytes may be 1 or 0 depending on data). We want a finite state machine that will search for message boundaries when given an input byte stream. The algorithm we'll use is to discard bytes until we see one with in[3]=1. We then assume that this is byte 1 of a message, and signal the receipt of a message once all 3 bytes have been received (done). The FSM should signal done in the cycle immediately after the third byte of each message was successfully received. Reset should be active high synchronous.

Consider a finite state machine that is used to control some type of motor. The FSM has inputs x and y, which come from the motor, and produces outputs f and g, which control the motor. There is also a clock input called clk and a reset input (synchronous, active low) called resetn. The FSM has to work as follows. As long as the reset input is asserted, the FSM stays in a beginning state, called state A. When the reset signal is de-asserted, then after the next clock edge the FSM has to set the output f to 1 for one clock cycle. Then, the FSM has to monitor the x input. When x has produced the values 1, 0, 1 in three successive clock cycles, then g should be set to 1 on the following clock cycle. While maintaining g = 1 the FSM has to monitor the y input. If y has the value 1 within at most two clock cycles, then the FSM should maintain g = 1 permanently (that is, until reset). But if y does not become 1 within two clock cycles, then the FSM should set g = 0 permanently (until reset).
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:

description:
You are a Verilog expert. Be concise and focused on the key points and avoid repetitive thoughts. Provide the Verilog code design directly.

Parity checking is often used as a simple method of detecting errors when transmitting data through an imperfect channel. Create a circuit that will compute a parity bit for a 8-bit byte (which will add a 9th bit to the byte). We will use "even" parity, where the parity bit is just the XOR of all 8 data bits.
Keep your reasoning process short and concise. Please complete the Verilog code below and return the complete module code:
```verilog

completion:
module top_module (
    input in,
    input [1:0] state,
    output reg [1:0] next_state,
    output out
);

    always @(*) begin
        case (state)
            2'b00: begin // State A
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b00; // A
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            2'b01: begin // State B
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b10; // C
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            2'b10: begin // State C
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b00; // A
                else next_state = 2'b11; // D
            end
            2'b11: begin // State D
                if (in == 0) next_state = 2'b10; // C
                else next_state = 2'b01; // B
            end
            default: next_state = 2'b00; // Default to state A
        endcase
    end

    assign out = (state == 2'b11) ? 1'b1 : 1'b0; // Output is 1 only in state D
endmodule

	input [7:0] in,
	output reg [7:0] pedge);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input [7:0] in,
    output reg [7:0] pedge);

    reg [7:0] prev_in;

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        pedge <= 0; // Reset every cycle
        for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++) begin
            if (!prev_in[i] && in[i]) begin
                pedge[i] <= 1;
            end
        end
        prev_in <= in;
    end

endmodule

	input [511:0] data,
	output reg [511:0] q);
completion:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input [511:0] data,
    output reg [511:0] q);

    reg [511:0] next_q;

    always @(*) begin
        for (int i = 0; i < 512; i++) begin
            if (i == 0) begin
                next_q[i] = 1'b0 ^ q[i+1];
            end else if (i == 511) begin
                next_q[i] = q[i-1] ^ 1'b0;
            end else begin
                next_q[i] = q[i-1] ^ q[i+1];
            end
        end
    end

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else begin
            q <= next_q;
        end
    end

endmodule

In many (older) serial communications protocols, each data byte is sent along with a start bit and a stop bit, to help the receiver delimit bytes from the stream of bits. One common scheme is to use one start bit (0), 8 data bits, and 1 stop bit (1). The line is also at logic 1 when nothing is being transmitted (idle). Note that the serial protocol sends the least significant bit first.

module top_module(
    input clk,
    input load,
    input ena,
    input [1:0] amount,
    input [63:0] data,
    output reg [63:0] q);

    always @(posedge clk) begin
        if (load) begin
            q <= data;
        end else if (ena) begin
            case (amount)
                2'b00: q <= {q[62:0], 1'b0}; // Shift left by 1
                2'b01: q <= {q[55:0], 8'b0}; // Shift left by 8
                2'b10: q <= {q[63], q[63:1]}; // Shift right by 1 (arithmetic)
                2'b11: q <= { {8{q[63]}}, q[63:8] }; // Shift right by 8 (arithmetic)
                default: q <= q; // No shift
            endcase
        end
    end
endmodule
